awd_titl_txt: Preparing Engineering Graduate Students for the 21st Century
awd_abstract_narration:
Through its project entitled "Preparing Engineering Graduates Students for the 21st Century (PEGS 21)," the University of California at Davis (UC Davis) will provide a coordinated program of recruitment, retention and workforce development strategies to increase the number and diversity of engineers entering the workforce with the highest level of expertise.  The program will provide fifteen scholarships for four years to attract low-income academically-talented applicants to engineering graduate programs at UC Davis.  Efforts to recruit students from underrepresented groups, namely first-generation college students and underrepresented minorities, lend to the potential broader impacts of this project.  PEGS 21 will have five components that include curricular and co-curricular elements: targeted recruitment of students from California institutions, many of which have large Hispanic student populations, through career fairs; multi-level mentoring at the pre- and post-enrollment stages; cohort development and academic skills training; workforce readiness guidance; and reduced time commitment for Teaching Assistant or Graduate Student Research appointments made possible by the S-STEM scholarship funds. PEGS 21 is expected to increase the number of low-income, academically talented, first generation engineering graduate students enrolling, graduating, and ultimately entering the workforce by at least sixty students over four years.  Their enrollment will provide the opportunity to systematically determine if extant curricular and co-curricular strategies are effective in overcoming noted barriers to flow-income, first-generation students' graduate degree completion.

The objectives are to: (1) increase the number of students applying to engineering graduate programs with an emphasis on low income academically talented first generation (LIATFG) students, (2) increase the admission rate of LIATFG students by improving the quality of submitted graduate applications, (3) increase the number of LIATFG students completing engineering graduate programs, (4) strengthen workforce skills of LIATFG engineering graduates, and (5) contribute to the body of knowledge about successful strategies to recruit, graduate and prepare LIATFG students for the 21st century workforce.  Building on the literature regarding graduate degree attainment for first generation college students, PEGS 21 will implement and investigate the impact of a set of strategies for overcoming barriers to the pursuit and/or completion of graduate degrees in engineering, thereby contributing to the knowledge base of efforts to broaden the participation of LIATFG students in advanced engineering degree programs.

por.por_cntn:
The Preparing Engineering Graduate Students for the 21st Century (PEGS21) program supported first-year graduate students from underrepresented groups. The overall goal of the program was to level the playing field by providing knowledge and academic social capital that low-income, first-generation students may not have.  The program focused on addressing five prominent barriers that many first-generation students face in transitioning from undergraduate to graduate study (Gardner & Holley, 2011).

  • Breaking the Chain: Students overcoming obstacles to enter and persist in graduate school without guidance from parents who did not have navigate these barriers.
  • Knowing the Rules/Ambiguity: Unclear expectations of graduate school. They may perceive their peers know the "rules of the game" while they do not know what is expected or how to navigate the system.
  • Living in Two Worlds: Students may not feel that they fully belong to either their family/culture or within academia. There may be misconceptions of what graduate school is by families/friends.
  • Seeking Support: Students can have difficulty building the support systems needed (whether they be social, academic, or financial) to persist to degree completion.
  • Balancing Act: The pace and intensity of graduate school can catch students off track, particularly in the first year. Students challenged by balancing their academic pursuits with their family relationships and responsibilities.

 

Project Objectives

PEGS21 objectives are to:

  • Increase the number of low-income academically talented first generation students completing engineering graduate programs and entering the workforce;
  • Investigate the effectiveness of extant curricular and co-curricular practices in addressing challenges to recruiting and retaining engineering graduate students;
  • Ensure the workplace readiness of these students thereby increasing the number of highly qualified engineers entering the workforce; and
  • Create a more diversified and inclusive workforce.

 

Program Highlights

At the heart of the program was the graduate student cohorts. The program had five cohorts of 10-14 scholars over its 7 years (58 total). These individuals participated in an interactive weekly seminar in their first year to discuss topics that align with the barriers above (e.g., difficult conversations with advisors, imposter syndrome, biases within academia, hate crimes against those of Asian, Asian-American, and Black individuals, time management, career pathways, library skills). These weekly discussions led to a bond for the students within the cohort and of the trust with the faculty and staff involved. Students were also provided a $10K stipend their first year (to reduce the time the needed to work) and a travel stipend for going to attend conferences for their professional development.

 

Other components of the program included graduate student recruitment from institutions with diverse student populations and development of a one-unit course to introduce UC Davis students to graduate school (Gearing Up for Grad School).

 

PEGS21 Lessons Learned

External evaluators reviewed PEGS21 scholar's reflective assignments, interviewed them (1:1 and focus groups) to gain insights on the program.  Highlights of lessons learned from external evaluators are listed below.

  • Financial support while appreciated was not sufficient to support low-income, first-generation students from underrepresented groups 
  • PEGS21 scholars valued a support system of peers and neutral mentors (i.e., a mentor who is they trust is independent of their faculty advisor) and the safe and trusting community provided by the PEGS21 cohort 
  • PEGS21 helped students learn the ?unwritten? rules of graduate school and how to meet expectations, develop professionally, and see new educational/career opportunities. The seminars helped reduce ambiguity and learn how to navigate graduate school.
  • Scholars identified the two PEGS21 mentors and the sense of belonging as the most effective part of PEGS21
  • An important part of the PEGS21 structure was that it was "high-touch", individual-focused and led by knowledgeable, empathetic, and approachable leaders. The importance of leadership to PEGS21 success was articulated consistently through PEGS21 scholars.
  • Features recommended for leadership of similar programs include:
    • Good listener
    • Non-judgmental
    • Compassionate/responsive
    • Strong knowledge of university systems and policies
    • Proactively help students get answers to their questions
    • Understand how to share life skills and coping strategies
    • Fluent in understanding the social, cultural, economic, and educational experiences of students from diverse backgrounds
    • Comfortable creating a safe space for open discussion amongst students
    • Comfortable using one's own life experiences to build bridges with students
    • Willing to engage in caring communication with cohort throughout the academic year

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2023
Modified by: Colleen E Bronner
por.por_txt_cntn:
The Preparing Engineering Graduate Students for the 21st Century (PEGS21) program supported first-year graduate students from underrepresented groups. The overall goal of the program was to level the playing field by providing knowledge and academic social capital that low-income, first-generation students may not have.  The program focused on addressing five prominent barriers that many first-generation students face in transitioning from undergraduate to graduate study (Gardner & Holley, 2011).

Breaking the Chain: Students overcoming obstacles to enter and persist in graduate school without guidance from parents who did not have navigate these barriers.
Knowing the Rules/Ambiguity: Unclear expectations of graduate school. They may perceive their peers know the "rules of the game" while they do not know what is expected or how to navigate the system.
Living in Two Worlds: Students may not feel that they fully belong to either their family/culture or within academia. There may be misconceptions of what graduate school is by families/friends.
Seeking Support: Students can have difficulty building the support systems needed (whether they be social, academic, or financial) to persist to degree completion.
Balancing Act: The pace and intensity of graduate school can catch students off track, particularly in the first year. Students challenged by balancing their academic pursuits with their family relationships and responsibilities.


 

Project Objectives

PEGS21 objectives are to:

Increase the number of low-income academically talented first generation students completing engineering graduate programs and entering the workforce;
Investigate the effectiveness of extant curricular and co-curricular practices in addressing challenges to recruiting and retaining engineering graduate students;
Ensure the workplace readiness of these students thereby increasing the number of highly qualified engineers entering the workforce; and 
Create a more diversified and inclusive workforce.


 

Program Highlights

At the heart of the program was the graduate student cohorts. The program had five cohorts of 10-14 scholars over its 7 years (58 total). These individuals participated in an interactive weekly seminar in their first year to discuss topics that align with the barriers above (e.g., difficult conversations with advisors, imposter syndrome, biases within academia, hate crimes against those of Asian, Asian-American, and Black individuals, time management, career pathways, library skills). Students were also provided a $10K stipend their first year (to reduce the time the needed to work) and a travel stipend for going to attend conferences for their professional development.

 

Other components of the program included graduate student recruitment from institutions with diverse student populations and development of a one-unit course to introduce UC Davis students to graduate school (Gearing Up for Grad School).

 

PEGS21 Lessons Learned

External evaluators reviewed PEGS21 scholar's reflective assignments, interviewed them (1:1 and focus groups) to gain insights on the program.  Highlights of lessons learned from external evaluators are listed below.

Financial support while appreciated was not sufficient to support low-income, first-generation students from underrepresented groups 
PEGS21 scholars valued a support system of peers and neutral mentors (i.e., a mentor who is they trust is independent of their faculty advisor) and the safe and trusting community provided by the PEGS21 cohort 
PEGS21 helped students learn the ?unwritten? rules of graduate school and how to meet expectations, develop professionally, and see new educational/career opportunities. The seminars helped reduce ambiguity and learn how to navigate graduate school.
Scholars identified the two PEGS21 mentors and the sense of belonging as the most effective part of PEGS21
An important part of the PEGS21 structure was that it was "high-touch", individual-focused and led by knowledgeable, empathetic, and approachable leaders. The importance of leadership to PEGS21 success was articulated consistently through PEGS21 scholars.
Features recommended for leadership of similar programs include:  

Good listener
Non-judgmental
Compassionate/responsive
Strong knowledge of university systems and policies
Proactively help students get answers to their questions
Understand how to share life skills and coping strategies
Fluent in understanding the social, cultural, economic, and educational experiences of students from diverse backgrounds
Comfortable creating a safe space for open discussion amongst students
Comfortable using one's own life experiences to build bridges with students
Willing to engage in caring communication with cohort throughout the academic year
